human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hospital follow-up after acute on chronic CHF exacerbation.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and stage 3 chronic kidney disease.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports being a football fan.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports bilateral ankle swelling.
Neurological: Denies any sleep disturbance.

VITALS

BP: 128/72.
HR: 79 bpm.
RR: 26.
SpO2: 99%.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distension noted.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate. There is a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: There is trace edema to the bilateral lower extremities.

RESULTS

Previous echocardiogram is reviewed and revealed a preserved EF of 55% abnormal diastolic filling and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to be cause by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that he should continue to monitor his diet and avoid salty foods. I advised him to weigh himself every day and call me if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral to nutrition provided for dietary education.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This was uncontrolled prior to his hospital visit.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of diet and home blood pressure monitoring.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered for further evaluation.

3. Kidney disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Due to patient's acute CHF exacerbation, this is to be monitored.
- Medical Treatment: Lab work ordered.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Acute CHF exacerbation.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kevin Patterson is an 82-year-old male who presents for hospital follow-up after an acute on chronic CHF exacerbation.

Mr. Patterson reports that he is feeling well. He had an acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure a couple days ago, during which he was tachypneic and required oxygen. He notes that he has been following an appropriate diet.

He is watching his diet and taking as much as possible. At times, he forgets to take his prescription medications. At this point, he believes that he may be on different blood pressure medications following his hospitalization.

He reports no shortness of breath and no difficulty sleeping since his discharge from the hospital.

Mr. Patterson admits that he does not need to exercise.

He endorses swelling in the lower extremities. He denies chest pain.

PAST HISTORY

Hypertension.
Stage 3 chronic kidney disease.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient is a retired steel mill worker. He lives independently.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Cozaar 100 mg daily.

Norvasc 10 mg by mouth daily as prescribed.

MEDICATIONS

Cozaar 100 mg daily.
Norvasc 5 mg by mouth daily.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram showed a preserved ejection fraction of 55% with abnormal diastolic filling. Mild to moderate mitral regurgitation was also present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Kevin Patterson is an 82-year-old male who presents for hospital follow-up after an acute on chronic CHF exacerbation.

Congestive heart failure.
• Echocardiogram was positive for a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, with mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, and abnormal diastolic filling.
• Medical Reasoning: His current presentation appears to be secondary to dietary indiscretions and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Treatment: Continue on Bumex 2 mg daily. He should restrict his sodium intake. We will obtain a 24-hour urine test in the near future to evaluate his protein quantification and kidney function. See a nephrologist to monitor Stage III chronic kidney disease.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: He is not currently compliant with his anti-hypertensive regimen, which has resulted in elevated blood pressure.
• Treatment: Continue with Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily. I have ordered a renal artery ultrasound to evaluate for secondary causes.

Stage 3 chronic kidney disease.
• Medical Reasoning: Hypertension and abnormal diastolic filling on his echo can be contributing factors.
• Treatment: We are ordering additional labs to monitor his progression. See a nephrologist in 3 months for his CKD.

Patient Agreements: Patient agrees and understands recommended changes.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is instructed to continue watching his diet and taking his medications as prescribed, to include Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily. The urine protein quantification and a 24-hour urine function need to be completed to monitor renal function.

The patient is also instructed to weigh himself daily; I advised him to check his weight in the morning. He is to contact me if he gains greater than 3 pounds in 2 days.

Patient agrees and understands recommended changes.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right ankle pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Gregory Hernandez is a pleasant 42-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right ankle pain and swelling. The onset of his pain began yesterday after he slipped and fell on the ice while taking out the trash. He states that he was unable to ambulate at the time of injury and that a friend had to help him up. He then proceeded to ice and elevate his ankle throughout the night. His pain has since improved and he is able to bear more weight on his right ankle, however he is still limping. He denies experiencing any numbness to his right foot. In addition to ice and elevation he has been taking ibuprofen for his pain, which has provided some relief. He does not recall any other previous injury to his right ankle.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he is very active and enjoys playing soccer. He currently plays for the community soccer league.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right ankle pain.

VITALS

Vitals signs look good today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Mild edema
NEURO: Normal sensation.
MSK: Examination of the right ankle: Ecchymosis is present. There is swelling over the lateral malleolus. Tenderness to palpation anterolaterally in the soft tissue. No laxity on anterior drawer and inversion stress. No bony tenderness on palpation of the foot. Neurovascular intact. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds with a strong dorsalis pedis pulse. Sensation is intact to light touch.

RESULTS

3 views of the right ankle were taken today. These reveal no evidence of fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right ankle sprain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. We discussed that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture and that he sustained a right ankle sprain. Treatment options were discussed. He was advised to keep his right lower extremity elevated, especially when seated. He will also continue to ice his right ankle. An Aircast was provided today to help stabilize his ankle. He is to also utilize crutches for the next 1 to 2 days followed by weight-bearing as tolerated. For pain control he can continue to take NSAIDs as needed. We discussed that he should see significant improvement in his symptoms over the next 2 weeks.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to assess his progress and to determine his return to play date. He is advised to call the office should his symptoms change or worsen prior to his next appointment.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Hypercholesterolemia.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient denies any history of smoking; however, they note that their parents smoked when they lived with them. They enjoy being outside and riding their bike on trails.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports a cousin who died of a heart attack in their 40's. but denies any family history of hypercholesterolemia.

VITALS

Blood pressure looks good.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Eyes
- Examination: No xanthomas noted.

Neck
- General Examination: Neck is supple without thyromegaly.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No hepatomegaly or splenomegaly.

RESULTS

Recent cholesterol level is reviewed and shows patient is elevated at 210.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Elevated cholesterol.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's previous tests are consistent with hypercholesterolemia.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that the American Academy of Pediatrics recommends children between the ages of 9 to 11 years old and again between 17 to 20 years old be screened for their cholesterol. We also discussed that studies link high cholesterol to pre-mature heart attacks. I advised the patient that genetic testing can be done to see if the problem is genetic or a secondary cause. They were also advised to follow a balanced diet with a variety of foods that are low in saturated fat and sugars, as well as remain active.
- Medical Treatment: Full cholesterol panel ordered. Hemoglobin A1c, CMP, thyroid study, and liver panel were also ordered. Genetic testing ordered. Referral to nutritionist provided.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 3 to 6 months after meeting the nutritionist for another cholesterol level.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain on exertion.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a medical history of diabetes type 2. She has not been formally diagnosed with hypertension, but her blood pressures have been trending high.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports family history of heart disease.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking metformin 500 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies diaphoresis or clamminess.
Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No JVD, swelling, or carotid bruits.

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort:
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, otherwise normal rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs. Pulses are equal.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No masses or tenderness. Soft, no guarding.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: 1+ nonpitting edema in the ankles. No calf tenderness.

RESULTS

EKG was obtained and reviewed in office today and is unremarkable. Hemoglobin A1c: 7.0

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Chest pain.
- Medical Reasoning: Considering her history of diabetes, possible history of hypertension, and family history of heart disease, I suspect her chest pain is likely unstable angina. Her recent EKG was unremarkable and there are no other signs of heart attack, but I am worried she may have some sort of a blockage causing her pain.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed proper protocol for sublingual nitroglycerin for chest pain. I advised her to go to the emergency department if the medication is not effective after approximately 5 minutes.
- Medical Treatment: We will have her start a regimen of baby aspirin at 81 mg daily, for which I have sent in a prescription today. I also sent a prescription for nitroglycerin up to 3 tablets every 5 minutes as needed. Finally, I am going to have her follow up with cardiology for further evaluation.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: She appears to be doing well on her current regimen.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to keep her appointment with ophthalmology for evaluation of diabetic retinopathy.
- Medical Treatment: I'm going to put in an order for a repeat hemoglobin A1c to check for any needed medication adjustments and have her follow up in 2 weeks. In the meantime, I want her to continue with metformin 500 mg twice daily and dietary modifications.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Several providers, including myself, have noted a trend of elevated blood pressures in the patient's chart.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to monitor her blood pressures at home over the next 2 weeks and report her readings to me via MyChart. This should help us determine if any adjustments need to be made to her new medications. We discussed the possible side effects of hydrochlorothiazide how this will hopefully reduce some of her swelling seen on physical exam. All of her questions were answered.
- Medical Treatment: I'm going to have her start hydrochlorothiazide at a low dose.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 2 weeks.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Elizabeth Gonzales is a 53-year-old female presenting to the clinic today with chest pain. This has been ongoing for the last 3 months and she mainly experiences it when she is walking, otherwise it is nonpresent. She describes the pain as a dull pressure type pain. She does not have nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea, nor any shortness of breath, diaphoresis or clammyness. She denies current chest pain.

Her EKG pre-dated chest pain and was performed in the clinic and appears completely normal.

In regards to her diabetes, she mentions that her blood glucose readings recently have been elevated because of inactivity. She has an eye exam due in 2 weeks but has not seen an ophthalmologist yet. She denies taking regular aspirin, high blood pressure medications for her diabetes, as well as. She denies side effects to the metformin. The patient expressed his she has had a history of diabetes, high blood pressure, and high blood pressure was found in other provider notes.

The patient previously was followed in cardiology and had a recent stress test that was normal. She has had heart disease run in her family.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Heart disease.

MEDICATIONS

Metformin 500 mg, taking two times a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: denies fevers, chills.
Cardiovascular: denies indicate chest pain.
Respiratory: denies indicate shortness of breath. Only during exercise.
Gastrointestinal: denies nausea, heartburn, abdominal pain, diarrhea.
Neurological: denies indicate headache.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional: well-appearing in no acute distress.
Eyes: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. Extraocular movements intact. Sclerae are anicteric, bilateral cataracts.
Neck: Supple. No jugular venous distention. No carotid bruits.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No crackles or wheezes.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No rubs, gallops or extra heart sounds. Pulses 2+ and equal in upper extremities. No clubbing or cyanosis.
Gastrointestinal: Soft. No guarding or rebound. No masses. No hepatosplenomegaly.
Musculoskeletal: No tenderness to palpation along the thoracic or lumbar areas. No tenderness in either sacroiliotic or sacroiliac areas. 1+ nonpitting edema bilaterally past the knees. No calf tenderness.

RESULTS

HgbA1c: 7%.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Chest pain.
- Medical Reasoning: She has a significant surgical history of diabetes for which she is not compliant with medical therapy for. There is a history of heart disease in the patient's family, which raises concern for ischemic etiology of the chest pain especially giving the high blood pressure as well. Heart issues ran in the patient's family, but she denies current smoking.
- Aggravating factors: Walking
- Easing factors: Rest
- Associated symptoms: Diaphoresis
- Medical Reasoning: Her EKG predated the onset of chest pain. I discussed concerns of angina and unstable angina with the patient.
- Additional Workup: I reviewed her EKG in the office today, which revealed no definitive changes to her chest pain.
- Medical Treatment: I recommended aspirin 81 mg daily and nitroglycerin for chest pain.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to the patient that we need to consider looking at how managing the blood pressure could help alleviate the chest pain. I discussed the medical necessity for these medications. I also provided her with medical instructions for how to use nitro.
- Medical Treatment: Patient agrees to all recommendations.

2. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Her diabetes controls have been suboptimal recently.
- Associated symptoms: Polyuria
- Easing factors: pesticide
- Medical Reasoning: She does have an eye exam scheduled soon.
- Medical Treatment: We will continue the current regimen of metformin 500 mg tablets, taking 2 tablets daily.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: She has a history of high blood pressure but it does not appear we have formally established diagnosis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed her elevated blood pressure today as well as medical necessity to begin treating it.
- Medical Treatment: I am going to initiate her on hydrochlorothiazide and have her monitor her blood pressure daily at home.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INJECTIONS

None today.

EXCUSED ABSENCE

None.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is do not exert herself if she experiences chest pain. She should call 911 or go directly into the emergency room.

FOLLOW-UP

The patient will return for a follow-up examination in 2 weeks.

ADDENDUM

Medical Record Review with patient present.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Bilateral knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sophia Jackson is a pleasant 30-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of bilateral knee pain. She was referred by her primary care provider. The onset of her pain began 6 months ago. She denies any specific injury. The patient describes her pain as a deep, achy pain. She locates her pain to the posterior aspect of her patellae. The patient also reports “creaking” in her knees. She denies any swelling or redness in her knees. Her pain is aggravated by transitioning from a seated position to standing as well as ascending and descending stairs. Her pain is alleviated by rest. The patient has been icing her knees and wrapping her knees with an ACE bandage. She also takes ibuprofen or Aleve occasionally for pain. She states she tries to be as active as she can. She enjoys running outdoors. The patient adds that she would run 5 to 6 miles per day; however, she is unable to go 0.5 miles secondary to the pain. She denies any previous injuries to her knees.

She works from home.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of an upper extremity fracture when she was in 6th grade.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports bilateral knee pain and crepitus. Denies swelling or redness in the bilateral knees.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

GAIT: Normal, no deformity present.
CV: Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
No edema
NEURO: Patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
MSK: Examination of the bilateral lower extremities: Abduction strength is 3/5. Remainder of muscle strength is 5/5. Examination of the bilateral knees: No overlying erythema, ecchymosis, or warmth of the skin appreciated. No effusion. Tenderness to palpation of the bilateral retinaculum. Positive patellar grind test. Knee pain with squatting. Negative Lachman test bilaterally. Negative anterior and posterior drawer tests bilaterally. Negative McMurray test bilaterally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the bilateral knees were reviewed today. These demonstrate no evidence of any fractures or osteoarthritis.

ASSESSMENT

Bilateral knee patellofemoral pain syndrome.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient regarding her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with patellofemoral pain syndrome. We discussed treatment options and I have recommended that we begin with conservative treatment in the form of formal physical therapy to increase her lower extremity strength, mobility, and correct any incorrect running mechanics. I encouraged her to take running easy for now. She can continue taking ibuprofen or anti-inflammatories as needed for pain. All questions were answered.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me soon.

human_note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle Morales is a pleasant 58-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of low back pain.

Onset of his pain began 2 weeks ago, when he was lifting a box of books and felt a pop. The pain is described as aching and sharp. His pain has been increasing since the time of onset and is beginning to radiate down his left leg. The patient denies any pain with sitting. He adds that he has a sedentary job. The patient states that his pain does not affect his job, however he feels that he does not want to be as active as he was previously. He tries to exercise a few times per week, however he is inconsistent. He denies any numbness, tingling, loss of sensation, weakness, and loss of control of his bladder or bowels.

The patient has been taking ibuprofen and Tylenol for pain, which provides some relief. He has not been evaluated for surgery.

SOCIAL HISTORY

He denies smoking. The patient has a history of playing soccer in the midfield position.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient states that his father has back pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports low back pain.
Neurological: Denies bowl or bladder control issues, numbness, tingling, decreased sensations, or weakness.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 130/70 mm Hg.
Respiratory rate: 18.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: I do not appreciate any murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory effort no respiratory distress. Clear to auscultation, bilaterally.
BACK: No evidence of trauma or deformity
NEURO: Normal sensation. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
MSK: Examination of the lumbar spine: No ecchymosis noted. Midline tenderness at the L4-5 disc space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion. Positive supine straight leg test.

RESULTS

The MRI of the lumbar spine was reviewed today. It revealed disc desiccation and a disc bulge with a paracentral disc herniation resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis.

ASSESSMENT

Lumbar back pain at the L4-5 disc space due to a herniated disc with radiculopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and MRI findings today, I have discussed with the patient that his MRI revealed a herniated disc with radiculopathy. We discussed treatment options for this and I have recommended that we begin with conservative treatment in the form of a corticosteroid injection. With the patient's consent, we will proceed with a corticosteroid injection into the lumbar spine today. The patient was made aware of the risks of bleeding, infection, nerve damage, blood vessel damage, reaction to the medication, including skin changes, swelling, and also, the risk of elevated glucose levels if the patient were diabetic.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle Johnson is a 24-year-old male who presents today to establish care for his low back pain. The patient reports that his pain started a couple of weeks ago when he felt a pop while lifting a box of books. Due to the incident, he has experienced stabbing and aching low back pain. He denies any current bladder/bowel incontinence, numbness, or tingling sensation. He previously experienced radiating pain down his left leg.

The patient's pain has been getting worse and he has been taking over-the-counter pain medications, which sometimes provide relief. Kyle is an active individual, exercising a few times a week.

He is employed as an Olympic weightlifting teacher working approximately 40 hours per week in a sedentary job. He has a history of playing soccer as a midfielder.

The patient has a family history of spinal conditions as his father has a history of chronic low back pain.

His review of systems are otherwise negative.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional
- Well developed and well nourished.

Cardiovascular
- Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Distal run and rhythm noted.

Respiratory
- Lungs: clear to auscultation bilaterally. Effortless respiratory effort.

Musculoskeletal
- Back: No overlying redness or bruising. The patient endorses midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space and right lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion. Supine straight leg test is positive.

Neurological
- No apparent cranial nerve deficits.
- Sensory: Cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact.
- Motor: 5/5 strength muscle groups in the upper and lower extremities. Proximally and distally.
- Reflexes: All are 2+ and symmetrical throughout. Bilateral patellar and Achilles reflexes present.

EXTERNAL CONSULTATION

The patient received an MRI prior to this visit, which indicates a disk desiccation, disk bulge with paracentral disk herniation. This results in moderate neural foraminal stenosis at the right L4-L5 foraminal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Kyle Johnson is a 24-year-old male who presents today to establish care for his low back pain.

Medical Reasoning
- The patient's symptoms are in line with lumbar back pain at the L4-L5 disc space due to a herniated disk with radiculopathy.

Patient Education & Counseling
- I have spent time reviewing the etiology of his symptoms. I have discussed the MRI findings and how it correlates with the pain and radiating symptoms he is experiencing.

Treatment Recommendation
- He is interested in receiving conservative treatment.
- I have discussed the risks and benefits of a lumbar epidural steroid injection with him, including the risk of infection, bleeding, nerve damage, and no relief.

Informed Consent
- The patient understands and consents to the recommended treatment plan.

Treatment
- Lumbar epidural steroid injection at the L4-L5 level was advised with a corticosteroid.

Patient Agreements
- He will follow up and contact the office if he does not respond to the injection or if he experiences complications.

Patient Pain Management
- I advised the patient to continue over-the-counter medications, such as Tylenol and ibuprofen, to help manage any comfort post-procedural discomfort.

INSTRUCTIONS

Should his symptoms fail to improve, the patient is advised to contact the clinic to discuss possible surgical intervention.

human_note:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Angela Powell is a pleasant 81-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The onset of her pain began 1 week ago, when she was running around with her niece and fell. At the time of the injury, she heard a pop and believes that she twisted her knee. She reports that she has been limping since the injury. The patient locates her pain to the medial and lateral aspects of her knee. She rates her pain level as a 4 out of 10, however this is increasing. Her pain is described as a throbbing pain. The patient has been taking Tylenol, which has provided mild and temporary relief, as well as wrapping her knee with kinesiology tape. She states that she is unable to take ibuprofen secondary to an ulcer.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left knee: Edema and effusion noted. Moderate ROM. Pain with flexion and extension of the knee. Negative Lachman's. Negative valgus and varus stress test.

RESULTS

4 views of the left knee were taken. These reveal no evidence of any fractures or dislocations. No other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Left knee pain, possible MCL strain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient that her x-rays did not reveal any signs of a tear. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. The plan is to place the patient in a knee immobilizer to provide increased support for the next week. I have also prescribed the patient tramadol 50 mg to treat her pain. She can take Tylenol as needed for breakthrough pain. I have also advised her to ice her left knee 3 to 4 times a day for 20 to 30 minutes at a time. I have advised her to refrain from running for the next 3 weeks. If her pain does not improve with the immobilizer, I will recommend obtaining an MRI.

She states that she injured her left knee and she actually felt her knee pop. The patient admits she has been limping since this event and the pain has been worsening. The patient has also been splinting her knee with kinesiology tape.

ALLERGIES
Unknown.

Musculoskeletal: Denies hip pain. Endorses increased pain with the inability to bear weight on the left side. Endorses difficulty weight bearing.

Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam reveals mild effusion and edema. Tenderness and pain to palpation medially. Full active range of motion despite pain to flexion and extension. Negative Lachman's test and negative varus and valgus stress testing.

PLAN

After evaluation and discussion of treatment options Angela Williams will likely BENEFIT FROM a knee immobilizer. I will provide a prescription for tramadol to Tina now. human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency room follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Diane Baker is a 28-year-old female with a past medical history significant for depression, and hypertension, who presents for emergency room follow-up.

The patient went for a walk yesterday and began to feel lightheaded. She started to fall, however she was with her boyfriend, who caught her. She presented to the emergency room after this. While in the emergency room, her blood pressure was nearly 200 and she had a headache.

Her blood pressure is typically normal, however will become elevated approximately one week a month. She notes it is typically elevated because she is traveling a lot that week for work. While traveling, she is not eating as well and does not monitor her blood pressure. The patient is taking her lisinopril as prescribed.

Regarding her depression, she states she is doing well. Last year she started therapy and she has been going once a week, which has helped. Her support system is great and includes her boyfriend, mom, and brother.

The patient notes she has a little bit of nasal congestion, which she attributes to her seasonal allergies. She denies chest pain and shortness of breath.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from seasonal allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Neurological: Endorses lightheadedness and a headache.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Trace pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram stable in comparison to last year.

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction. Stable heart murmur.

ASSESSMENT

Ms. Diane Baker is a 28-year-old female with a past medical history significant for depression, and hypertension, who presents for emergency room follow-up.

PLAN

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: This is not controlled at this time. The patient presented to the emergency department yesterday with an elevated blood pressure, presyncope, and headache. She has been compliant with lisinopril, but her blood pressures have been spiking once a month based on home monitoring; however, she admits to not taking her blood pressures while traveling recently. A recent EKG revealed changes from her chronic high blood pressure.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril to 40 mg once a day.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She will continue to check her blood pressures and report them to me through the patient portal. We will have to make adjustments if necessary.

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well with weekly therapy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current management strategies. No medication to start at this time.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She can contact me if she needs anything.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Alan Butler is a 61-year-old male presenting with complaints of shortness of breath.

The patient states that over the weekend, he took a very long bike ride for approximately 3 hours, and when he returned, he was very lightheaded and short of breath. He notes that it was difficult to catch his breath afterward. He endorses that he had mild chest pain at that time, however, it eventually went away after about an hour. He denies any fever at this time or any other symptoms at this time. No other members in his family have been sick.

The patient is currently taking Imitrex as needed for his migraines. His migraines are under control and he avoids exposure to bright lights.

The patient is currently taking Protonix for his reflux and he is doing well with this.

The patient had cataract surgery about 4.5 months ago. He notes that his vision is okay since then.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Endorses a cough. Endorses shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses reflux.
• Neurological: Endorses migraines. Endorses lightheadedness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Supple.  No jugular venous distension.
• Respiratory: Slight expiratory wheezing bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
• Musculoskeletal: Trace edema in the bilateral lower extremities.

RESULTS

Pulmonary function test are within normal limits.

X-ray of the chest is unremarkable.

CBC: Within normal limits.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 61-year-old male who presents for shortness of breath.

Shortness of breath.
• Medical Reasoning: I reviewed the patient's chest x-ray, pulmonary function test, and labs which were all normal. He does have slight expiratory wheezing bilaterally on exam. I suspect his episode of shortness of breath was due to an exacerbation of asthma.
• Medical Treatment: I would like to prescribe an albuterol inhaler, 2 puffs every 4 hours as needed for wheezing or shortness of breath.
• Specialist Referral: I have referred him to pulmonology for an asthma workup.

Acid reflux.
• Medical Reasoning: This seems stable.
• Medical Treatment: I recommended the patient continue Protonix.

Migraines.
• Medical Reasoning: This problem is also stable. Continue on Imitrex as needed.
• Medical Treatment: I recommended he continue Imitrex as needed for migraines.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 2 weeks or sooner if his conditions worsen.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up to an abnormal labs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joyce Price is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for COPD, congestive heart failure who presents for follow-up to an abnormal lab finding.

The patient reports that she has been feeling really tired lately. She reports that over the past couple of months, her energy has really gone down. She used to be really active, trying to be as healthy as she can be with running and climbing, at least an hour or two a day. Over the past month, her activity has slowly decreased. She reports that, due to her fatigue, she has not been able to keep up with her exercise. She reports that she had noticed a little weight loss, but she believes that was due to her doing really well with her exercises.

The patient reports that her COPD is doing well. She reports that she has not been smoking since she quit. She reports that during the changes of the season, it gets a little harder for her to breathe, but she believes that is because of her allergies.

From a congestive heart failure standpoint, she reports that she has been doing really well with her diet. She reports that she has been staying away from French fries and all the other salty foods that she likes to eat. She denies any swelling in her legs.

She reports that she has a good support system with her boyfriend and her brother.

She reports that she has not noticed any blood in her stool at this time. She denies that her stools are dark or black in color. She denies that she has had any abnormal bleeding between menses. The patient denies any other symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, fever, chills, or malaise.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills. Endorses weight loss. Endorses fatigue.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory:   Endorses shortness of breath with seasonal changes.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia, melena.
• Genitourinary: Denies abnormal bleeding between menses.
• Neurological: Positive for dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Supple without cervical lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. No gallops or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Tenderness to palpation to the right lower quadrant.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is 8.2.
Labs are within normal limits.
Anemia labs: Still pending.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Joyce Price is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for COPD, congestive heart failure, who presents for follow up of abnormal labs.

1. Abnormal labs.
• Medical Reasoning: Her recent hemoglobin level was low at 8.2. Her available anemia labs were normal, but we need to wait for her pending labs for a definitive anemia diagnosis.
• Additional Testing: I would like to obtain an endoscopy and colonoscopy to evaluate for gastrointestinal bleeding.
• Specialist Referrals: We will put in a referral to gastroenterology to perform her endoscopy and colonoscopy.

2. COPD.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well. She ceased tobacco use several years ago and continues to abstain from this.
• Medical Treatment: I do not think she needs any inhalers at this time. She should continue to stay away from smoking.

3. Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well and continues to follow dietary modifications, particularly with limiting her sodium intake.
• Medical Treatment: Continue on Toprol and lisinopril, as well as her current dose of Lasix 20 mg a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab findings.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joyce Alexander is a 50-year-old female with a past medical history significant for COPD and congestive heart failure who presents for follow-up to an abnormal lab finding.

The patient endorses fatigue, dizziness, and recent weight loss. She denies blood in her stools, melena, hematochezia, and menorrhagia. She also denies chest pain, shortness of breath, fevers, chills, body aches, abdominal pain, and edema.

The patient reports quitting smoking several years ago. Emphysema changes are still present on chest x-ray. She attributes recent SOB to seasonal allergies.

Per the patient, she consumes a low-salt diet.

She reports a good support system.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Reports fatigue and unintentional weight loss.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies blood in her stools, melena, hematochezia, and altered bowel habits.
• Genitourinary/Female Reproductive: Denies menorrhagia.

VITALS

Vitals in the office are stable.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Respiratory-Chest: No cervical lymphadenopathy. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard.
• Gastrointestinal: Right lower quadrant tenderness on palpation. No edema in the lower extremities.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin level was 8.2.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Endoscopy and colonoscopy referral
• Discussion
o We need to investigate why your hemoglobin is low. I am waiting for you to have your anemia labs come back, let’s track them and see if you can get more information. Will refer you to endoscopy and colonoscopy for further workup to ensure you are not bleeding internally.
• Patient Education
o Endoscopy and Colonoscopy: We need to look at your hemoglobin level, and this will show if you have internal bleeding.

Anemia
• Medical Reasoning
o We are waiting for your anemia labs to come back to further evaluate your condition.
• Patient Condition
o The patient is anemic.
• Patient Education
o We are waiting for your anemia labs to come back before we move forward. It is important that we determine the cause of your anemia.

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
• Medical Reasoning
o Continued cessation of smoking is recommended, as this will have the best positive impact on her breathing.
• Patient Condition
o The patient is doing well from a pulmonary standpoint.
• Patient Education
o The patient is advised to continue with the smoking cessation. No further recommendations for at this time of the visit.

Congestive heart failure
• Medical Reasoning
o Her exam and symptoms are stable on current medical regimen.
• Patient Condition
o The patient continues to have stable congestive heart failure.
• Pharmacology
o The patient has lisinopril and metoprolol were continued as prescribed. She also continues on her current diuretic dosing of Lasix 20 mg daily.

Patient Education
• We are going to continue to monitor you closely at your future visits.

Care Plan
• Referral to endoscopy and colonoscopy
• Continue lasix at 20 mg a day.
• Continue metoprolol and lisinopril as prescribed.

Home Medications
• Calcium citrate
• Vitamin D.

INSTRUCTIONS

I will continue to monitor her progress and future visits.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Evelyn Morris is a 56-year-old female with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, prior carpal tunnel release, and a herniated disc. She presents for her annual exam.

The patient states she has been doing okay with her herniated disc in her back. She has not had any back pain or any limitations in movement. She had a steroid injection for her herniated disc several months ago, which has been doing well.

Her right carpal tunnel release was performed a couple of years ago and she is back to work. She has full range of motion and it feels really good. No numbness or tingling in her hands.

She has had prior stenting for her heart and heart vessels in the past. Over the last month, she reports chest pain approximately 3-4 times a week with ambulation. Her chest pain does resolve with rest. The pain is described as burning and is located in the middle of her chest. She denies pain at rest.

She has had a little bit of nasal congestion from allergies. The patient denies, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, or lower extremity edema.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion form allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea. Endorses chest pain with exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Integumentary: Well-healed surgical scars on her right wrist.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction at 45% with a slight mitral regurgitation.

ECG prior coronary artery disease. No new changes.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Evelyn Morris is a 56-year-old female with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, prior carpal tunnel release, and a herniated disc. She presents for her annual exam.

Status post right carpal tunnel release.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well postoperatively. She has returned to work and denies any recurrent symptoms.

Herniated disc.
• Medical Reasoning: She has been asymptomatic since receiving a steroid injection several months ago. I do not think we need to refer her for any further steroid injections or physical therapy at this time.
• Patient Education and Counseling: If she has any recurrent symptoms, she will let me know and we can take it from there.

Coronary artery disease.
• Medical Reasoning: She reports a burning chest pain with exertion approximately 3 times per week for the past month. Her recent echocardiogram demonstrated a reduced ejection fraction of 45%.
• Medical Treatment: Continue aspirin and Toprol. Initiate Crestor 20 mg once daily.
• Additional Testing: We will order a cardiac stress test and a lipid panel for further evaluation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

He states it has been a pretty stressful winter and spring, as they have been very short-staffed at work. The patient admits to recent weight gain. He has been hosting friends over vacation and at the beach this summer so the diet is off the charts out the window.

The patient has a history of depression and is doing well. He has been consistent with utilizing his Zoloft 50 mg a day. The patient states this has been a challenging year and a half. He is sleeping okay at night, occasionally waking up at 5 a.m. Denies thoughts of self-harm or suicidal ideation

His high blood pressure has been under good control recently

• Constitutional: Endorses weight gain.
• Psychiatric:   Endorses stress.

Hypertension.

• Medical Treatment: He will continue lisinopril 5 mg daily.

Depression.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Upper respiratory infection.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD, who presents with an upper respiratory infection.

The patient reports that about a week ago he started to get a cold, which has worsened in the last 2 or 3 days. He endorses some postnasal drip for the beginning of the week, however, it has seemed to move into his chest. He denies chest pain other than his chest congestion. He was able to exercise prior to getting sick. He denies anyone else being sick in his house. He denies fever and shortness of breath.

Regarding his high cholesterol, he states he has been pretty good for the most part. He did a little travel over the last week or so and his diet was not great but for the most part it is pretty good. He is on Crestor 20 mg a day and is tolerating it well. He denies any muscle aches. He had his bypass grafting last year and is doing great.

The patient is fully vaccinated for COVID-19.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses post nasal drip.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest congestion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Psychiatric: Endorses obsessive compulsive disorder.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: Positive cervical lymphadenopathy
• Respiratory: Rhonchi and wheezing bilaterally.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Oxygen Saturation: 96%.

RESULTS

Lipid panel: Within normal limits.

COVID-19 test: Positive

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan Harris is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery bypass grafting, hyperlipidemia, and OCD who presents today for upper respiratory symptoms.

COVID-19 Positive.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with upper respiratory symptoms and his COVID-19 test was positive today. He has received both doses of the vaccination. His symptoms seem to be very mild at this time. His oxygenation is good at 96%.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I advised him to quarantine for 10 days and we discussed that he should try to avoid family members. I asked him to call me if his symptoms worsen.

Hypercholesterolemia.
• Medical Reasoning: He is doing well on Crestor 20 mg once a day. His cholesterol looked good on his most recent lipid panel.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged him to continue to watch his diet.
• Additional Testing: We will go ahead and order another lipid panel for 6 months.
• Medical Treatment: He can continue Crestor 20 mg once a day.

History of coronary artery bypass grafting.
• Medical Reasoning: He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting approximately 1 year ago. His coronary artery disease seems to be under control currently. He denies chest pain.
• Additional Testing: We will do a stress test in 6 months.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Joint pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. James Moore is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and lupus, who presents today with some joint pain.

The patient reports he has been " putting a few more miles on the bike each day ". His bilateral knees have been sore in the last 3 to 4 days. He states his bilateral knees are equally painful. He notes stiffness and soreness in the morning and, by the end of the day, he feels the same sensation. He endorses swelling and redness in his knees which reduces in severity by the afternoon. The patient denies any other associated fatigue. He denies any injury to his knees. He denies pain in any other joints including his elbows, wrists, or shoulders.

In regards to his coronary artery disease, Mr. Moore states he is compliant with his aspirin and Crestor. He denies chest pain or shortness of breath.

The patient denies recent symptoms related to his lupus over the last year.

He denies fever, chills, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomitting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and erythema in bilateral knees.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Edema and slight erythema of bilateral knees. Slight effusion of the right knee with pain to palpation. Decreased range of motion in bilateral knees.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee is unremarkable. No bony abnormalities or fractures were noted.

Electrocardiogram stable in comparison to last year.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. James Moore is a 57-year-old male with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease and lupus, who presents today with some joint pain.

Lupus.
• Medical Reasoning: This has been stable and asymptomatic for the past year, but the patient reports increased joint pain and inflammation in his bilateral knees lately. ​His recent knee x-ray was unremarkable, so I am concerned that this is a lupus flare.
• Additional Testing: We will order an autoimmune panel for further evaluation.

Coronary artery disease.
• Medical Reasoning: He is asymptomatic at this time. He has discontinued Plavix but continues with daily aspirin and Crestor. His recent EKG was unremarkable.
• Additional Testing: We will order a lipid panel and a repeat echocardiogram.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Joint pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

James McCann is a 57-year-old male who presents today with joint pain. He believes that this pain is from an exacerbation of his lupus due to increasing his physical activity.

The patient reports that his pain is localized to his knees and is bilateral. His pain is worse in the morning when he first wakes up and gradually improves throughout the day due to frequent biking. The patient notes that there is minimal swelling of his knees, greater in the morning than in the afternoons. The patient denies experiencing any fatigue, fever, and/or injury.

In reviewing the patient's record, it's been a while since I last saw him in the clinic. I know we placed a stent last year. His antiplatelet therapy was discontinued and he is now only taking the lowest dose of aspirin. He is tolerating this well. He is also tolerating his current statin therapy without any issues. He denies any chest pain or shortness of breath.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient's medical history is significant for coronary artery disease and lupus.

MEDICATIONS

Aspirin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

He denies any fatigue, fever, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, or vomiting.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Two out of six systolic ejection murmur. No rub, gallop, or clicks.
Respiratory: Lungs sound clear bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Bilateral knee edema and some slight erythema. There is a slight effusion present on the right knee. The range of motion is decreased bilaterally. Pain to the right knee.

RESULTS

We obtained a right knee x-ray today. The results indicate that there is no bony abnormality, fracture or osseous lesion. The right knee X-ray from today is unremarkable.

An electrocardiogram has been completed. Although he has a history of an ejection murmur, the EKG is normal. No acute changes or ischemic findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Bilateral knee pain in a patient with a history of lupus.
- The patient experienced increased bilateral knee pain after increasing his exercise. X-ray of the right knee from today did not reveal any acute processes, so a lupus flare would be a possibility. We discussed treatment option and the benefits of steroids and rest.
- X-ray of his right knee today is unremarkable.
-Ordered autoimmune panel.
2. Coronary artery disease.
- The patient is postpeating stent placement from last year. He has already undergone an EKG in office which was reviewed. He has been compliant with Clopidogrel. As he was doing well with the aspirin regimen, the clopidogrel was discontinued. He has been doing well post-stent placement. Six minute walk test is 480 meters.
- Additional echocardiogram and lipid panel have been ordered today.

INSTRUCTIONS

He will follow up with us as needed.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Check up for abnormal labs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Natalie Price is a 39-year-old female here today for a check up for an abnormal labs. She has a history of high blood pressure, diabetes type 2, and right ACL repair.

The patient states she had routine blood work done last week and they said her blood sugars were high. She was instructed to follow up to get some more work done. She denies having any symptoms.

Regarding her diabetes, her diet has been really great lately. She has been avoiding sugars and watching her weight. The patient is power walking 30 minutes every day. She is checking her blood sugars every morning. The patient has continued to utilize metformin 1000 mg a day, which was increased at her last visit.

She states her high blood pressure has been stable with lisinopril. The patient has a cuff at home to measure her blood pressure herself.

Regarding her knee, she had an ACL repair on her right knee about 5 years ago and everything has been going well. She has not had any issues with mobility.

She denies chest pain, shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea, headaches, and abdominal pain. She denies any difficulty urinating or burning when she urinates.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary pain.
• Neurological: Denies headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Head and Face: Normocephalic and atraumatic.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy. No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft and nondistended.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.1.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Natalie Price is a 39-year-old female with a history of high blood pressure, diabetes type 2, and right ACL repair. She presents today for evaluation following abnormal labs.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: She is asymptomatic but her recent lab work demonstrated an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.1. She has been compliant with metformin 1000 mg daily, dietary modifications, and monitoring her blood glucose levels at home.
• Additional Testing: We will check her CBC, CMP, and lipid panel.
• Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg daily. Initiate Jardiance 10 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to follow her dietary modifications closely.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: This is stable and well-controlled on her current dose of lisinopril. She does monitor her blood pressures at home.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril at current dose.

Status post right ACL repair.
• Medical Reasoning: She is doing well postoperatively.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue with her physical activity and exercise regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Howard is a 60-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents for follow up of his chronic problems.

In regards to his depression, the patient notes that it has been a crazy year and a half. He experienced a lot of anxiety while getting ready for Thanksgiving but it is starting to resolve now. He denies suicidal and homicidal ideation. The patient and his wife began going on walks and gardening over the summer and he notes good relief of his depression from this; however, the season has changed and he needs an alterative method of management. He has preferred to avoid medications in the past.

The patient is still taking metformin for his diabetes. He notes some dietary indiscretion with Thanksgiving but he is doing better with this now.

In terms of his hypertension, he notes he is compliant with lisinopril. He did buy a blood pressure cuff and is checking his blood pressure at home. His blood pressures have reportedly been good.

He denies chest pain, dyspnea, abdominal pain, hematochezia, or weight loss.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia or abdominal pain.
• Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety and depression.  Denies suicidal and homicidal ideations.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Well-developed, well-nourished, in no apparent distress.
• Neck: No carotid bruits appreciable.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base, heard previously.
• Musculoskeletal: 1+ nonpitting edema bilaterally.

RESULTS

EKG was unremarkable.

Diabetic labs revealed an elevated hemoglobin A1c of 8.

ASSESSMENT

Bruce Howard is a 60-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and hypertension who presents for follow up of his chronic problems.

PLAN

Depression.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been doing well with going on morning walks; however, this has ended due to the cooler weather. He continues to decline the use of medications for this issue.
• Medical Treatment: We will defer initiating medication at this time.
• Specialist Referrals: I will refer him to psychiatry to engage in talk therapy.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient admits to recent dietary indiscretion. His most recent hemoglobin A1c was elevated at 8 percent. He is compliant with metformin.
• Additional Testing: I will order a repeat hemoglobin A1c in the next couple of months. I will also order a lipid panel.
• Medical Treatment: We will increase his metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been monitoring his blood pressure on a regular basis. Blood pressure is well controlled at this time. He has a systolic ejection murmur that continues to be heard on exam.
• Additional Testing: I will order an echocardiogram to reassess the heart murmur.
• Medical Treatment: He will continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

[doctor] for your cholesterol though , you're on the high dose of atorvastatin or lipitor to protect the arteries , so we really wan na keep you on that .
[patient] yeah , no problem .
[doctor] i want you to quit smoking , but we've had this battle before .

[doctor] hmm . and then , we will leave everything else the same . we'll get the labs today and we'll see you back here in four months . sound good ?

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up for diabetes management, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, peripheral vascular disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Maria Martin is a 75-year-old female who presents today for follow-up for diabetes.

The patient’s blood glucose levels are poorly controlled and her most recent hemoglobin A1C is 9.9%. She denies increasing glimepiride to 4 mg twice a day as advised but confirms she is compliant with 2 mg twice a day. She mostly denies reducing sugar and carbohydrate intake, although she opts for wheat bread, she does not have pasta at home, and she does not drink much soda and instead drinks club soda or seltzer water. She reports that her diabetic eye exams are up to date and she follows with Dr. Sanchez at Optimum Optometrists. She recently underwent cataract surgery and received a new prescription for her glasses, noting improvement in her vision to one eye and displeasure with the lens in her other eye.

She confirms compliancy with her blood pressure medications of metoprolol 50 mg daily, lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg daily, and amlodipine 10 mg daily. The patient intermittently completes at home blood pressure checks and reported seeing a systolic BP of 116 a few weeks ago. She is also compliant with her atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and reports tolerating it well.

The patient is still experiencing bilateral hip, thigh, and foot pain related to peripheral neuropathy, noting her mobility is limited but she is walking as tolerated.

Ms. Martin does continue to smoke cigarettes and denies interest in cessation, although she agreed to begin thinking about it.

She is currently experiencing a productive cough with clear sputum that she attributes to her recent congestion.

The patient is also experiencing a slower urine stream, but it appears stable, and she contributes her urinary symptoms to aging. She also has nocturia on occasion which she contributes to her increased fluid intake in the evenings.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Hypertension.
Hyperlipidemia.
Peripheral vascular disease with neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Current tobacco smoker.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Metoprolol 50 mg tablet. Take 1 tablet daily.
Lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide 20/25 mg tablet. Take 1 tablet daily.
Amlodipine 10 mg tablet. Take 1 tablet daily.
Atorvastatin tablet.
Metformin.
Glimepiride 4mg tablet. Take 2 tablets by oral route 2 times per day.

VITALS

Blood pressure 140/60.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
No rasping, wheezing.

Cardiovascular
Normal heart rate and regular rhythm. Carotids and pulses are normal. S1 and S2 are crisp. No murmurs.

Gastrointestinal
No nausea or vomiting.

Extremities
Bilateral Diabetic Foot Exam: No edema with palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses bilaterally. No skin breakdown. Thickened nails.
Sensory Examination: Mildly decreased sensation in the tips of the first and second toes bilaterally.

RESULTS

Hemoglobin A1C 9.9%.

ASSESSMENT

• Type 2 diabetes mellitus.
• Hypertension.
• Hyperlipidemia.
• Peripheral vascular disease.

PLAN

Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Increase glimepiride to 4 mg tablets two times per day. I counselled patient on the signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia, although I don’t think she is at a great risk of hypoglycemia. There will be no change to her metformin dose. I counselled the patient on limiting her carbohydrate intake to support improved glycemia. We will recheck her Hemoglobin A1c and complete a kidney function test today.

Peripheral vascular disease
I counselled patient on improving frequency of moisturizing her feet. Improved glycemia would also benefit her neuropathy. If symptoms worsen, we will consider medication to control symptoms, but not at this time due to the patient has already reached polypharmacy.

Hypertension
Blood pressure appears to be well controlled based on checks completed at home. The patient will continue with amlodipine, metoprolol, and lisinopril/hydrochlorothiazide.

Hyperlipidemia
I will continue with atorvastatin as previously prescribed. If patient were to improve her diet, this would likely be beneficial as well.

INSTRUCTIONS

Finish current prescription of glimepiride 2 mg, 2 tablets 2 times per day. Refill will be 4 mg tablet, 1 tablet 2 times per day. Reduce carbohydrate intake overall to improve glycemia. Call the office with questions or any signs or symptoms of hypoglycemia.

dialogue:
[doctor] patient mrn : abc123 . date of birth : january 1st , 1960 . patient is a 60 year old , right-handed male , referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling .
[doctor] hello , mr. cook . how are you doing this morning ?
[patient] hi , dr. martinez . this weekend was a bit rough . i've had this numbness and tingling for a few weeks now .
[doctor] so it's in both of your hands ?
[patient] yes , ever since my car wreck last december when i broke them ... well , once they healed , i mean , i noticed it more , the tingling and the numbness .
[doctor] and you still wear the splint only on the right wrist ?
[patient] no , i also wear the left sometimes . the right is just worse , but the splint helps . both have really gotten worse over the last month . when i broke them , my right wrist was definitely in worse shape . i've also been having some s- mild stiffness in my neck too . i hit my head during the accident , and they told me it was a contusion .
[doctor] and where would you say the tingling and numbness is ?
[patient] on this side , it goes from here and here up to about here . on the other side , it's from here to here .
[doctor] i see . so on the right side , you're pointing from the middle and ring finger , all the way up the forearm . and on the left , the symptoms extend from the pinky and ring finger . and is there any pain or just tingling and numbness ?
[patient] eh , it's mainly just sore . sometimes they throb , but overall , they feel weaker too , especially when i'm using them . the tingling happens more when they hurt , but when it goes away , the tingling is dull .
[doctor] and when do you feel these symptoms ?
[patient] well , really , i guess , just more so at night , and they come and go throughout the day .
[doctor] okay . and do you experience any loss of sensation in your hands or fingers ?
[patient] like , feeling something ? no , not that i can really think of . though , in general , they may be less sensitive than they should be , but i can still feel . they also gave me some nerve pain medicine , but i have n't been taking it like i should .
[doctor] and are you still on the coreg for hypertension and the lexapro for anxiety ?
[patient] yes , i'm still taking those . i had prediabetes too , but i got it under control by changing my diet .
[doctor] and no history of thyroid issues , correct ?
[patient] nope .
[doctor] all right , thank you , mr. cook . okay , first , we'll go over your review of systems . correct me if i'm wrong in any of this .
[doctor] constitutional , you have fatigue and weight gain ; gi , you have excessive appetite and bloating ; eyes have floaters ; cardiovascular shows shortness of breath and leg swelling ; endocrine , you're always hungry ; skin , you have some nail bed changes , dryness , itching ; musculoskeletal , you have gout and muscle pain . and the remainder of the review of systems is negative .
[patient] yep , that's all correct .
[doctor] all right , we're going to go ahead and do the neurologic examination . let's look at the right hand first . can you feel this ?
[patient] yeah , but a little less on these two fingers .
[doctor] sensation is normal , except pin prick sensation diminished in third and fourth fingers on the right .
[doctor] and how about on the left ?
[patient] um , yeah , but these two a little less .
[doctor] sensation is decreased in the fourth and fifth fingers on the left
[doctor] okay , let's test your reflexes now . reflexes are 1+ and symmetric ; 2+ knees ; toes are downgoing bilaterally .
[doctor] all right , i'm going to tap on your right wrist . do you feel anything ?
[patient] yeah , it feels like a zing up my wrist and something into my elbow too .
[doctor] and how about the left side ?
[patient] yeah , same on that side too .
[doctor] tinel sign positive at both wrists and both elbows . rest of exam is normal .
[doctor] all right , so what i am seeing today is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or , potentially , this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome . however , your symptom presentation suggests car- bilateral carpal syndrome , as the nerve in your wrists are aggravated by your past trauma . this is causing the pain and tingling you were describing to me .
[patient] okay , so how do we make it better ?
[doctor] first , i want to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from . we'll need to schedule you for a nerve test , which is called an emg test . they will measure the responsiveness of your nerves to truly pinpoint where you are having your issues .
[patient] that sounds fine to me .
[doctor] great . after the tests are complete , you can return here for a follow-up visit . if you're still having symptoms , we can consider a referral to our hand clinic , possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release se- surgery . you could also refer ... we could also refer you to an orthopedist for the same treatment .
[patient] sounds good , doc .
[doctor] all right , keep wearing your splints , and i will see you after those studies .
[patient] thank you .
human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Numbness and tingling of both hands.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Elijah Cook is a 60-year-old male referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling of both hands.

The patient complains of numbness, tingling, and pain in both hands which began in 12/2019 after he broke both wrists in a motor vehicle accident and which has progressively worsened since then. He continues to wear a splint on the right wrist all the time and on the left only intermittently, which he states is because the right wrist was injured more severely in the accident. The sensation radiates from the hands into the forearms and is equal bilaterally. The 4th and 5th fingers in the left hand and 3rd and 4th on the right-hand tingle. He states that his fingers are sore with palpation and seem weaker than before. Any exertion exacerbates the tingling, and after something exacerbates the pain, the tingling seems "dull". The symptoms come and go and seem to occur mostly at night. He denies complete loss of sensation in any of his fingers, but states that they seem less sensitive than they should be. He reports mild stiffness in his neck. He notes that he did hit his head during the car accident and was diagnosed with a contusion. He states that he has been given "nerve pain medicine” but has not been taking it.

He currently takes Coreg for his hypertension and Lexapro for his anxiety. He reports a history of prediabetes, which he has brought under control via dietary changes. He denies any history of thyroid issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional Symptoms: Easily fatigued, weight gain.
• Eyes: Floaters.
• Cardiovascular: Bilateral peripheral edema.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Excessive appetite, abdominal bloating.
• Musculoskeletal: Gout, muscle pain.
• Integumentary: Dry itchy skin, nail bed changes.
• Endocrine: Excessive hunger.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
Pinprick sensation intact in the 3rd and 4th fingers on the right hand and 4th and 5th fingers on the left hand. Reflexes are 1+ and symmetric, 2+ knees. Toes down going bilaterally. Tinel’s sign positive at both wrists and elbows.

ASSESSMENT

• Bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
Mr. Cook is a 60-year-old male referred today for evaluation of numbness and tingling of both hands. His symptom presentation and exam findings today suggest this is bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome or, potentially, this could also be bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome.

PLAN

Diagnosis discussed with patient, I explained that the nerves in his wrists are aggravated by the past trauma causing the pain and tingling. Further testing is indicated to measure the responsiveness of the nerves to determine exactly where the nerve irritation is coming from. We will plan for a follow-up visit after the EMG testing is performed. If still symptomatic, we can consider a referral to our Hand Clinic possibly for injections or carpal tunnel release surgery. We could also refer to an orthopedist for the same treatment.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow-up after EMG testing.
