human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of seasonal allergies, diabetes type 2, and hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking metformin 500 mg as well as hydrochlorothiazide every day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies any fever or body aches.
HENT: Reports sore throat and nasal congestion.
Respiratory: Reports productive cough with green phlegm. Denies any shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: Elevated at 144/72 mm Hg. The remainder of the vital signs look good.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No frontal sinus tenderness. Bilateral maxillary sinus tenderness.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Mouth:
- Examination of Throat: Erythema of the pharynx. Tonsils are symmetrical. No exudates.

Neck
- General Examination: Anterior cervical adenopathy.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No edema.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Cough.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with symptoms similar to an upper respiratory infection. Most likely it is a virus that is causing her symptoms, especially as she reports being around some else with similar symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained that we often let the virus run its course while we treat her symptoms. I advised her to be cautious with over-the-counter cough medicines as certain ones can affect her blood pressure and diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: She increase her fluid intake. I recommended she try Coricidin HBP as a safer alternative to her cough medicine. The patient should rest frequently. I will order a COVID-19 test.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Stable with medication.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue with dietary restrictions.
- Medical Treatment: We will continue her on her metformin 500 mg twice a day. Repeat hemoglobin A1c will be due at her next visit.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Her blood pressure is elevated today, and it sounds like it has been trending higher at home as well.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue limiting her intake of salty foods. >I recommend that she take her hydrochlorothiazide in the morning because it can result in more frequent urination.
- Medical Treatment: We will increase her dose of hydrochlorothiazide to 25 mg once a day. She will continue checking her blood pressure a few times a week at different times of the day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

Constitutional: Reports sore throat and cough.
Respiratory: Reports sore throat, frequent cough.

Neck

- Throat: Erythema.

Cardiovascular

Vitals reviewed. Reports a history of elevated blood pressure, currently 144/72 mmHg. Pain 141/72 mmHg, when the last measured her blood pressure. Examination today reveals anterior cervical adenopathy, maxillary sinus tenderness and erythema in the pharynx.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1.  Upper respiratory infection.
- Medical Reasoning: Her symptoms are most consistent with a viral upper respiratory infection and considering she was exposed to family member who also has similar symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that it is most likely a virus and she should just let it run its course and continue with supportive care. We suggested she increase her water intake, rest as much as possible avoid salt intake, take Coricidin HBP as needed.
- Orders: She agrees to COVID-19 testing today. Will notify her of results when they are available.

2.  Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Her blood glucose levels have been well controlled. She is doing well with her diet and checking her blood sugars at home daily as recommended.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of continuing metformin 500 mg daily and diet modification. Ongoing monitoring is recommended.
- Orders: Will be due for her hemoglobin A1c at her next visit in 3 months.

3.  Hypertension, labile.
- Medical Reasoning: Her blood pressure has been slightly elevated, ranging up to 140/70 on her home recordings. She is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily, but this is not fully controlling her blood pressure. Therefore, we will increase the dose to 25 mg daily for better blood pressure control and continue to monitor her labs and blood pressure logs at home.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of good blood pressure control and how we will monitor this over the next several weeks with the increased medication dosage.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

FOLLOW UP

She will schedule a follow-up appointment in the office in 6 weeks.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Rogers is a pleasant 50-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain.

For the past few weeks, the patient has been experiencing constant pain isolated to the left shoulder. She denies any known injury or trauma; however, she is very active and is currently renovating her basement. She denies any associated numbness or tingling as well. While movements such as reaching and lifting exacerbate her pain, full flexion of the shoulder is the most severe. Her pain is also exacerbated if she lays on her shoulder, which subsequently causes sleep disturbance due to her being uncomfortable. She typically takes Tylenol Extra Strength, 2 tablets every 6 to 8 hours, for aches and pains associated with her active lifestyle, and doing so reduces her shoulder pain to 2-3/10 on the pain scale. Without medication, she rates her pain as 7/10.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient denies any previous trauma or injury to left shoulder.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that she has a very active lifestyle. She has also been renovating her basement recently.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that she has been taking Tylenol Extra Strength, 2 tablets every 6 to 8 hours.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies left shoulder numbness or tingling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is brisk at less than 3 seconds.
NEURO: Motor and sensation in the left shoulder are intact to light touch.
MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grip bilaterally.

RESULTS

X-ray imaging of the left shoulder was performed and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I believe this is most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. We discussed the nature of this condition in detail, and I have ordered an MRI for further evaluation. I'm going to put in a referral for 6 to 8 weeks of physical therapy, during which time she should continue with Tylenol as-needed. If her symptoms do not improve, we can consider administering a steroid injection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 2 weeks.

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mrs. Betty Webb is a pleasant 63-year-old female who established care with the clinic today. The patient presents with complaints of left shoulder pain that has been ongoing for the last three weeks.

The patient denies any recent trauma. She notes that she is very active and has been spending a lot of time renovating her basement. This is why she was unable to identify any direct cause for the onset of her symptoms. She does not recall any previous episodes of left shoulder pain.

The pain is present all of the time. She reports her pain today as 7/10 without the use of Tylenol and 2/10 to 3/10 with Tylenol. The patient denies any numbness or tingling traveling down her left arm and into her hand.

The patient states that she usually sleeps on her left side but is unable to do so at night due to her pain.

The patient also states that when she tries to reach for something or lift anything, she experiences a lot of pain as well.

She is self-treating at home with Tylenol 500 mg every 6 to 8 hours.

MEDICAL HISTORY

She denies any previous history of left shoulder pain.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been very active during the last 3 weeks due to home renovation.

MEDICATIONS

Acetaminophen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain.

VITALS

All normal.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Examination of the left shoulder reveals limited active and passive range of motion. There is some tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. There is no tenderness at the sternoclavicular joint or clavicular joint. The patient has good hand grip bilaterally. Neurovascular examination of the left arm shows that capillary refill is brisk in less than 3 seconds. Motor and sensation is intact to light touch. No significant findings on examination.

RESULTS

Review of x-ray of the left shoulder reveals no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

- Left shoulder pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and x-ray findings, I discussed these with the patient. Her overall presentation appears to be consistent with rotator cuff tendinopathy. I advised the patient that given that her x-ray does not reveal any type of bony abnormality, we can continue with conservative management. We discussed that this may include physical therapy, as well as the addition of Tylenol as needed for pain control.

Therefore, I am going to order an MRI of the left shoulder for further evaluation. Once we get the results, I will refer the patient for physical therapy for approximately 6 to 8 weeks. I advised the patient that if her symptoms do not improve with physical therapy she may be a candidate for a steroid injection. I advised the patient that this is a surgical procedure and can provide significant pain relief.

INSTRUCTIONS

We will have the patient follow up with me in approximately 2 weeks.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Matthew Allen is a pleasant 40-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain. The onset of his pain began yesterday after he went up for a rebound while playing basketball and felt a pop in his knee. He states that he experienced swelling and difficulty with ambulation following this incident. He locates his pain today to the medial aspect of his knee. His pain is described as aching and is rated at 4 out of 10. In terms of his swelling, he states that this has improved some. He is also able to weight-bear, but he finds that he is favoring his left leg while doing so. His tried treatments include Tylenol with some relief as well as rest.

The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes. He reports that he does not check is blood pressure at home very often, but he typically runs 140 to 150 range over 80. He is taking 5 mg of Norvasc daily. In terms of his diet, he states that he enjoys eating whatever he likes. His most recent A1C was 7.2. He is taking metformin 500 mg daily, however there are days where he skips this because of gastrointestinal upset. He denies checking his blood sugar at home consistently and that when he does check he has been around 150.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports playing basketball, however this most recent event was the first time he played in 2 years.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports he is taking Norvasc 5 mg daily, metformin 500 mg daily, and Tylenol.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure is 140/80 today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory effort no respiratory distress
MSK: Examination of the right knee: Pain with palpation over the medial aspect. Mild pain with flexion and extension. Edema, swelling, and ecchymosis noted. Mild redness. Negative varus and valgus stress test with firm endpoint.

RESULTS

4 views of the right knee were taken. These reveal no evidence of any fractures or dislocations. No other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Right knee MCL strain.
Diabetes.
Hypertension.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to his current symptoms. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the right knee to further evaluate for a possible MCL tear. In the meantime, he will continue with Tylenol for pain relief. I have also prescribed him meloxicam 15 mg for pain and swelling. He will be placed into a knee immobilizer and has been advised to remain non weight-bearing for the next couple of weeks.

In terms of his diabetes, he was advised to start logging his blood sugars daily and to avoid eating large amounts of strawberries. He will also be provided with a referral for a consult with a nutritionist.

For his hypertension, we are going to increase his Norvasc to 5 mg daily as his blood pressures have been elevated. We discussed our goal is for him to get closer to the 120/80 range.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to review his MRI results.

Matthew Guzman is a pleasant 35-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of right knee pain. He explains he was playing basketball yesterday, trying to get a rebound, came down on his right knee, and felt that knee pop. He felt as if he had swelling around the joint, stating the knee is symptomatic on the medial aspect.
The patient states that he is typically his weight-bearing. He was doing so very minimally when the injury occurred.

The patient rates his pain as 4/10. He reports he is taking Tylenol as needed and is currently wearing a brace which he feels has been helpful. He reports that his pain has improved since the initial onset of the injury.

The patient also complains of mild swelling and increased ecchymosis to the area of the knee.

The patient also reports having a headache and sore throat for 2 days.

The patient was not officially diagnosed with diabetes, however, was previously diagnosed with hypertension. The patient explains he was seen last year, and his A1C was 7.2. He is no longer taking his metformin due to gastrointestinal issues and treats his hyperglycemia with diet. The patient also reports his home blood pressure monitor reads 150-160/80 mmHg, and he is currently taking Norvasc 5 mg daily.

The x-ray of the right knee was reviewed and was unremarkable.

1. Right knee pain.

We discussed the considerations to undergo an MRI for formal evaluation of this injury. The patient will continue with Tylenol as needed. Orthotic recommendation was discussed and provided. The patient understands and agrees with the treatment plan including knee immobilizer use, activity modifications, and physical therapy. 3. Uncontrolled diabetes.
- Medical reasoning of uncontrolled diabetes was reviewed. The patient does report that his home blood glucose readings are improving. I advised him to continue checking and recording his blood glucose levels daily. We discussed the importance of dietary modifications and exercise. I recommended that he restart taking his metformin 500 mg daily, and advised him to take it with food to help alleviate gastrointestinal side effects. I advised him to follow-up with a nutritionist for further guidance.

Patient Agreements:
- Right knee

 Patient sees brodiatrics nutrition.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to go over his MRI and overall progress.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Elevated and fluctuating blood pressures.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of essential hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports he enjoys playing golf.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports he is taking lisinopril 20 mg twice per day, atorvastatin, and occasional Tylenol.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Reports heaviness in chest. Denies heart palpitations or syncope.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
Neurological: Reports headache and lightheadedness. Denies syncope.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Mild bibasilar rales, but no wheezes or rhonchi. Excellent air movement.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from prior.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Elevated blood pressure.
- Medical Reasoning: I do think his blood pressure is uncontrolled and we need to make some adjustments to his medication.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The patient and I discussed that he should stay well hydrated during warm weather. I explained he loses more fluid when perspiring and will need to increase his fluid intake as needed. We discussed that drinking 6 to 8 standard glasses of water per day is an adequate amount. He may want to increase that amount if he is feeling particularly dehydrated or as he increases his activity level. I cautioned him from drinking more than 2 alcoholic beverages a week.
- Medical Treatment: I am going to increase his lisinopril to 60 mg twice per day. Prescription for 25 mg per day of hydrochlorothiazide provided as well. He will check his blood pressure twice a day for the next 2 weeks.

2. Hyperlipidemia.
- Medical Reasoning: Stable.
- Medical Treatment: I will order a cholesterol panel, CBC with differential, and comprehensive metabolic panel. We will also obtain an urinalysis to assess his kidney function as well. He will continue the current management with his atorvastatin.

3. Osteoarthritis.
- Medical Reasoning: Stable.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue to stay as active as he can without overdoing it. We discussed that walking and golfing are great activities for him to engage in.
- Medical Treatment: He can take Tylenol for any mild pain.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks.

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient was evaluated by his primary care physician, who ordered a computed tomography scan.

The patient describes the pain as "sharp," "stable," and "unstable." It is mostly located on his left side.

The patient also reports excessive daily water consumption and nocturia. He exercises by riding a bike occasionally and is a student who has been doing well in school.

He was previously diagnosed with strep but does not know the cause of the symptoms.

The patient's brother smokes but does not smoke in the home. The patient's siblings are currently healthy.

The patient denies any weight changes but has an increased appetite. He also denies changes in fatigue.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever or weight changes.
• Eyes: Denies visual changes.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, heartburn, hematemesis, melena, nausea, or changes in appetite.
• Genitourinary: Reports nocturia. All other systems review negative for urinary frequency or urgency.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• CVS: Rate and rhythm regular. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No edema.
• Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in cervical and thoracolumbar spine. Bilateral trapezii muscle spasms. No midline vertebral tenderness to palpation. No paraspinal muscle tenderness. No costovertebral angle tenderness. No symptomatic left piriformis. Left sacroiliac joint tenderness to palpation.
Head, Ears, Eyes, Nose, and Throat: Tonsils appear atopic. No erythema or exudates. No pharygnoconjunctival congestion.

EVIDENCE- BASED ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

• Strep Throat: The patient has a significant history of recurrent episodes. I diagnosed this today. I have counseled the patient on the signs and symptoms of strep infections.
o GFR Abnormalities: Comparative CT revealed some glomerular nephritis. If the repeat mono spot is positive, this can be review by a nephrologist. Some symptoms included an increased GFR, back pain, and fatigue. We did touch on the options of the safe day T and tonsillectomy.
o Nutrition Abnormalities: I have reviewed with the patient that his dietary habits are therapeutic for managing his kidney dysfunction.

PROCEDURE

• X-ray of neck.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he is a teacher.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking lisinopril 20 mg daily and metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports "feeling warm". Denies chills.
HENT: Reports nasal congestion, sore throat, and sinus pressure.
Respiratory: Reports productive cough with yellow sputum. Denies dyspnea.
Musculoskeletal: Reports body aches and right knee pain. Denies right knee instability.

VITALS

Temperature is 98.4 today.
BP: 125/62.
Heart rate is nice and slow in the 80s.
SpO2 is 97% on room air.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: Pain to palpation to the bilateral maxillary sinuses.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Nose: Erythema and edema of the nasal turbinates bilaterally with associated yellow discharge.
- Examination of Throat: Uvula is midline. Pharynx without erythema, swelling, or exudate in the peritonsillar space.

Neck
- General Examination: Bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy noted.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Coarse rhonchi present bilaterally that clears with cough.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No masses or tenderness.
- Auscultation: Bowel sounds normal in all 4 quadrants.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right knee: Pain to palpation. Decreased flexion and extension. Ecchymosis present medially. No evidence of an effusion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Cough.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a cough likely due to a viral syndrome such as mild bronchitis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that antibiotics are not needed at this time, however, if his symptoms worsen we will consider a chest x-ray. - Medical Treatment: Continue over-the-counter medications. I will prescribe guaifenesin 600 mg twice a day.

2. Right knee pain.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's physical exam is consistent with a right medial lateral ligament strain.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed physical therapy will be beneficial for strengthening the right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Prescription for meloxicam 15 mg once a day provided. Referral to physical therapy provided. Right knee x-ray ordered.

3. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure in office today looked great and appears stable at this time.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day. I will order a lipid panel.

4. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient does not check his blood sugar at home and admits to not watching his diet.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of diet as there can be complications with diabetes such as kidney dysfunction and eye problems that we want to avoid. He was also advised of the importance of blood sugar monitoring.
- Medical Treatment: Hemoglobin A1c ordered. Continue metformin as prescribed. Start blood sugar monitoring and report levels through patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

We will contact the patient with his lab results when ready.

Medical assistant visit note.

Billy Greeley is a 74 year old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation and management for his cough.

The cough started about 1 week ago and he started to bring up some yellow phlegm. He noted that he has not been feeling well the last 2 days. He denies taking his temperature but admits that he has felt warm.

He denies fever, chills, or wheezing. He reports sinus pressure, post-nasal drip. He endorses mild aches.

He denies shortness of breath in the last week. He denies sore throat.

He endorses being congested. He denies any shortness of breath.

Pulmonary Exam
• Auscultation of Lungs (Thorax, Lung, Chest): Normal breath sounds bilaterally.

Muscoloskeletal Exam
• Exam of Right Knee (Myalgia, Muscle Pain, Achilles Reflex): Pain to palpation over the medial knee with decreased active and passive flexion/extension.

Medical History
• Medical Cause of Exam: Also notes history of hypertension which is controlled with lisinopril and history of diabetes which he reports not being compliant with.

Medical Rendering
• Upper Respiratory Infection: He presents with signs of an upper respiratory infection today. It might be the cause of his underlying congestion. X-ray can be done if symptoms do not improve.

Hypertension: Has been well controlled on lisinopril 20 mg daily. I will also order a lipid panel for him to have done to ensure all is well from that standpoint.

Right Knee Pain: Exam findings are consistent with a right medial collateral injury. I have recommended physical therapy and a knee x-ray.

Education and Counseling

• Hypertension: Continue taking lisinopril 2Omg once daily. A lipid panel was also provided.
• Right Knee Pain: A x-ray will be ordered to assess if any bone injuries have been sustained. We will also be providing a prescription for meloxicam 15 mg once daily and PT referral.

Additional Testing

IMPRESSION

Upper respiratory infection.
Hypertension, well controlled.

PROVIDER TO PATIENT INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is encouraged to monitor his blood sugar intake and report his blood sugar results to us through the patient portal.

The patient is encouraged to watch his dietary intake as well as check his daily blood sugar levels regularly.

Plan

Based on the exam findings and medical history provided, I have recommended the following treatment plan.

Upper Respiratory Infection
• Symptomatic medical treatment: guaifenesin 6OOmg twice daily.
• Radiology referral(s): X - Ray Lower Joint(s) of – Right Knee.

Hypertension
• Medical treatment: Continue taking lisinopril 2Omg once daily.
• Laboratory referral(s): Lipid panel.

Right Knee Pain
• Medical treatment: Meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
• Physical therapy referral(s).

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Headache and high blood pressure.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Neurological: Reports blurry vision, dizziness, and headaches.

VITALS

Blood pressure today was 172/98. Oxygenation is within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention. No carotid bruits.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from last year.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Slight edema to bilateral upper extremities. 1+ pitting edema noted in the bilateral lower extremities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Hypertension, uncontrolled.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is is elevated.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that this could be multifactorial; for example, her diet, her medications regimen, or the medication she is currently on could be a factor in her elevated blood pressure. I encouraged the patient to take her current medication regimen today. I encouraged her to monitor her blood pressure 3 times a week. We also discussed the patient speaking to our nutritionist to help her diet. I recommended a DASH diet.
- Medical Treatment: She will continue her current medication regimen.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's diabetes is uncontrolled.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to continue taking her blood sugars to make sure that the change in medication is effective.
- Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1500 mg.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 4 weeks.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Uncontrolled hypertension and headache.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Theresa Lopez is a pleasant 53-year-old female who established care at our office. The patient reports that she has had hypertension for a longtime. She states that she is noncompliant with her current hypertensive medication which she states is chlorthalidone because the medication gives her a stomachache. She denies any recent increase in frequency of the stomachache. The patient states that she takes her medication approximately every other day. She reports that she has been off and on for the past month of throbbing headaches on the top of her head. She states that the headaches are sometimes accompanied with dizziness and a blurry vision. The patient has been taking Tylenol every other day.

The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes that is currently untreated. She believes that she may have eaten too much Easter candy which may have resulted in elevated blood glucose levels. She states that she is compliant with a diabetic diet although she eats McDonald's often. The patient states that her favorite McDonald's dish is the fillet of fish, although she has been advised by the physician to avoid this in the future.

The patient informs me that her husband has made her feel a lot calmer since her last visit.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that she is noncompliant with her antihypertensive, chlorthalidone medication. She has been taking a Tylenol every other day.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient enjoys eating out at McDonald's because she loves fast food. She eats McDonald's often despite being advised to follow a low sodium diet.

FAMILY HISTORY

Denies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports headaches.
Chest: Denies chest pain or shortness of breath.
Psychiatric: Reports stress relief when with her husband.
Eyes: Reports vision changes.
Ears, Nose & Throat: Reports dizziness.
Cardiovascular: Reports history of untreated hypertension.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports abdominal pain with antihypertensives.
Skin: Reports edema in upper and lower extremities.
Endocrine: Reports history of untreated diabetes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 172/98, Respiratory rate is 18, oxygen saturation is 97% on room air, heart rate is 78.
Neck: No carotid bruits, No jugular venous distension bilaterally.
Respiratory: Lungs are clear bilaterally.
Cardiovascular: S2 is heard. 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur. No carotid bruits bilaterally.
Extremities: 1+ pitting edemabilateral.

ASSESSMENT

1. Uncontrolled hypertension.
- Medication-related history of noncompliance, which is likely partially responsible.
2. Headache.

PLAN

At present, her current treatment regimine will be continued. The patient will be counseled by a nutritionist regarding dietary modifications. We will also increase the dose of metformin to 1500mg.

I will also continue to monitor her prescriptions and lab results as necessary.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Steven Reed is a pleasant 60-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of back pain. The onset of his pain began 2 years ago after he fell and landed onto his back while playing basketball. His pain is rated at 7 out of 10 and is described a sharp with occasional throbbing. At times his pain will radiate down his left lower extremity. He also reports experiencing intermittent numbness in his toes. Prolonged standing exacerbates his pain and makes him feel weak. He is able to get some pain relief when laying on his side. In terms of his bowel and bladder habits, he reports 1 episode of incontinence over the last 2 years which he believes was due to prolonged standing and possible alcohol consumption. He other denies any other changes and denies loss of sensation in the genital or rectal area. He has tried an injection in the past, but notes that he does not like needles and had to be held down. Pain medication was tried but he is unable to recall the name of the medication. He also attended physical therapy with minimal relief. Currently he states that he is not very active and tends to watch tv all day. He has gained 80 lbs over the last year.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports previously playing basketball, but he is now not very active and sits at home all day. He has a history of smoking, but denies smoking currently.

FAMILY HISTORY

Patient reports his 4th cousin has scoliosis.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Genitourinary: Denies bowel or bladder changes.
Musculoskeletal: Reports back pain.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation is in 95 percentile range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No Murmur.
NEURO: Decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at the L4 dermatome. Patella and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.
MSK: Examination of the lumbar spine: No overlying erythema or ecchymosis. Midline tenderness along the L4-5 disc space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion and extension. Positive supine straight leg raise.

RESULTS

The MRI of the lumbar spine was reviewed. This shows evidence of disc desiccation and a disc bulge with a paracentral disc herniation resulting in moderate right neural foraminal stenosis.

ASSESSMENT

Chronic lumbar back pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and MRI findings today, I explained to the patient that he has a herniated disc at L4-5 with radiculopathy. We discussed the nature of the diagnosis as well as treatment options. I have recommended that we start with a spinal corticosteroid injection under fluoroscopy. The nature of the procedure was discussed. A prescription was given today to help with his anxiety during the injection as he states he does not tolerate needles. We also had a long discussion regarding pain medication. I advised him that we can do up to 4 injections per year and that we need to hold off on proceeding with pain medication until we assess his progress. I also explained to him that pain medication is not a long term solution and that if he remains symptomatic, it is possible surgery would be recommended.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will return for follow-up after to assess his progress after his spinal injection.
ai_note:
CC:

Low back pain radiating to the left leg.

HPI:

Steven Jackson is a 27-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of low back pain. The pain initially began approximately 2 years ago after he fell playing basketball. He reports falling directly onto his back. He was evaluated by his primary physician and was referred for physical therapy and has had lumbar injections in the past. He reports the exercises were not helpful. The patient also reports that the lumbar injections administered by Dr. Reddy in the past were not helpful. He also notes that his pain is a 7/10 and describes it as sharp with intermittent throbbing. The pain originates at his back and travels down into his left leg, causing it to be numb at times. He states that he only experienced one bowel incontinence episode. He feels improved lying on his side but the pain worsens when sitting or standing. He notes that he sits all day as he has gained 80 pounds in the past 1 year. The patient reports the pain is exacerbated when standing for prolonged periods but relieved when lying down. He denies experiencing a fever or history of smoking.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Patient reports a history of weight gain. Patient reports a history of prior low back physical therapy and lumbar paraspinal injections.

SOCIAL HISTORY:

The patient denies smoking tobacco.

FAMILY HISTORY:

Positive for family member with scoliosis.

MEDICATIONS:

Reports taking unidentified white tablet, which was likely gabapentin. No current pain medication prescription in his electronic medical record at this time.

VITALS:

Normal resting heart rate without a murmur on cardiac auscultation.

RESULTS:

Labs: Demonstrates an abnormal C-reactive protein level.
Imaging: Lumbar MRI findings show disc desiccation and a disc bulge with posterocentral disc herniation resulting in severe foraminal stenosis, most significant on the right at the L4-L5.

ASSESSMENT:

The patient is a 27-year-old male who presents with chronic low back degenerative disk pain secondary to a herniated disc at L4-5 and L4-5 radiculopathy.

PLAN:

After review of today's visit, we will trial lumbar epidural steroid injection for his low back pain symptoms. The patient was initially hesitant about this approach due to a fear of needles, but after a thorough discussion, he has agreed to this recommended treatment. To alleviate his worries and reduce his anxiety, I will order a single dose of an oral anxiolytic for him to take 3 hours prior to the injection, to be prescribed as needed. We have informed the patient that the ultimate goal is to minimize his pain medications, as his MRI findings demonstrate foramen stenosis that would benefit from corticosteroid administration. If after this treatment, he still has persistent back pain, we may explore the benefits of a long-term weight loss program and discuss anterior lumbar interbody fusion.

INSTRUCTIONS:

The patient was informed and understands the recommended treatment.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Wright is a pleasant 36-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right shoulder pain. The onset of her pain began 3 weeks ago, when she was painting on a ladder when she reached out to catch herself because she fell. She states that she braced herself with her right arm. The patient reports that she was able to get up and continue painting. She states that she experienced numbness and tingling in her arm and hand when she initially injured her right shoulder, however this has resolved. She states that she iced her arm and took Advil for pain. The patient denies any previous shoulder pain. She reports constant pain with lifting her arm overhead. The patient rates her pain level as a 6 out of 10 without medication and a 4 out of 10 with medication.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness and tingling.

VITALS

Vitals look good today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Brisk capillary refill of less than 3 seconds.
NEURO: Normal strength and sensation. Neurovascularly intact distally. Equal bilateral response to sensation and touch.
MSK: Examination of the right shoulder reveals limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness over the sternoclavicular joint. Good strong bilateral hand grips.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right shoulder taken today reveals no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the right shoulder. I referred her to formal physical therapy to strengthen her right shoulder. She will continue to take Advil as needed for pain.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks for re-evaluation.

Right shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Baker is a pleasant 51-year-old female who presented to the clinic today to be evaluated for right shoulder pain of 3 weeks duration. The onset of her shoulder pain was due to a fall approximately 3 weeks ago. The patient was up on a ladder painting, felt, and braced herself with her upper extremity. She has no prior shoulder issues. The patient denies numbness or tingling in her arm. She has been remodeling her house. She was initially using ice and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories for the pain. Her pain level is 6/10 without medication and 4/10 with medication. The patient is unable to lift her arm overhead without pain but can otherwise move it without difficulty.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fevers.
Musculoskeletal: Positive for right shoulder pain.

VITALS

Vitals are stable today.

PHYSICAL EXAM

- Right Shoulder

- Inspection: Normal.
- Palpation: Tender to the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular joint.
- ROM
- Active: Limited.
- Passive: Limited.
- Neurovascular: Brisk capillary refill less than 3 seconds. Equal and bilateral response to sensation and touch. Strength 5/5. Good strong bilateral hand grips.

STAT STUDIES REVIEW

Right shoulder x-ray taken today reveals no fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Baker, a 51-year-old female, presents with right shoulder pain of 3 weeks duration.

Rotator cuff tendinopathy.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient is a 51-year-old female who presents with a history of right shoulder pain of 3 weeks which was initiated by a fall. Based on her clinical presentation, steering examination, and x-ray findings today I do believe she has rotator cuff tendinopathy.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the natural history of her symptoms and that physical therapy can be very beneficial.
- Medical Treatment: I advised her to continue taking NSAIDs, ice, and to participate in physical therapy to increase her range of motion and strength for her shoulder.
- Additional Testing: We will schedule the patient for an MRI.
- Specialist Consults: I will refer her to physical therapy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow-Up: The patient will follow up to the clinic in 2 weeks for a reevaluation and treatment plan.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Vision changes in the right eye.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of high blood pressure.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports he is smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Eyes: Reports right eye vision changes.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Eyes
- Examination of the right eye: Posterior chamber intraocular lenses present bilaterally. Right eye cornea is clear without NVI and cup-disc ratio is 0.2. Fundus of right eye shows retina is intact 360 degrees without holes or tears noted, and RPE changes in fovea. Posterior segment shows drusen of the macula, retinal thickening, and presence of subretinal fluid and exudate accumulation. Positive hemorrhage
Examination of the left eye: Cornea is clear. No NVI. Cup-disc ration is 0.3. RPE changes in fovea. No hemorrhage noted or subretinal fluid noted. Retina is attached appropriately.

RESULTS

OTC:
Drusen deposits under the RPE. SRF accumulation and choroidal neovascular membrane can also be visualized.

Fluorescein angiography:
Reveals that the focal area of the leakage in the right eye is consistent with neovascular age related macular degeneration.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Wet macular degeneration.
- Medical Reasoning: The diagnostic test and eye exams are consistent with neovascular age-related macular degeneration, also called wet macular degeneration.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained the nature of the diagnosis and that this is advanced to a stage that usually leads to more severe vision loss happening. We discussed this happens when those abnormal blood vessels start to grow beneath the retina leaking fluid and blood. Secondary to that, it creates a large blind spot in the center of his visual field. He was advised that this is the most common cause of severe vision loss. I explained the treatment plan at length. He understands he is going to be injected in the vitreous portion of the eye after we numb the eye, so he is not going to feel any pain. I advised injections given over time can slow the rate of the vision decline and maybe even stop it. However, I also have to let him know that there could be a situation where he may still note a small amount of vision loss, but this is his best chance of maintaining that vision for as long as he can. Additionally, patient was counseled on the importance of taking his blood pressure medication. Questions were invited and answered today.
- Medical Treatment: Lucentis injections once a month with his first being performed today.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

� Left Eye:
-- Visual Acuity: N/A
-- Posterior chamber intraocular lens.
-- Cornea is clear.
-- No neovascularization of the iris or angle.
-- Cell and flare are not seen.
-- No corenal staining or edema.

-- Drusen near the fovea are noted.
-- RPE changes in the fovea.
-- Retina mild is attached appropriately.

VITALS REVIEWED

The patient presented today with an elevated Blood Pressure 150/90.

RESULTS RECEIVED

OCT of the right eye review shows drusen deposits under the RPE, subrtinal fluid present.

Fluorescein angiography reveals focal area of leakage in the right eye, consistent with neovascular age related macular degeneration.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

Matthew Chance is a 73-year-old male who presents for further evaluation of decreased vision in the right eye.

Neovascular age related macular degeneration is present. The diagnostic tests and physical examination performed today are consistent with this diagnosis.

Wet age related macular degeneration is a condition in which abnormal blood vessels start to grow beneath the retina. The blood vessels leak fluid and blood which causes the center of the vision to have a large blind spot.

Once a month Lucentis injections are recommended for this condition. The good news is that the patients will receive a numbing agent; therefore, he will not feel any pain during the injection or procedure. Over time, injections can slow the degeneration of vision decline; overall slowing the development of the disease.

The patient does smoke, I counseled him on the importance of smoking cessation and the impact of his condition, and advised to avoid smoking.

The patient has a history of hypertension. He has not been compliant with his medication. It is important for him to continue to monitor his blood pressures take his prescribed T more often.

INSTRUCTIONS

Three months follow up in our office for reassessment.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joe Reed is a pleasant 42-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of a right knee injury. The patient sustained this injury when he was skiing with some friends. He states the front end of his skis dug into the snow and he ended up doing a cartwheel through the air until he stopped halfway and felt a pop with immediate pain in his right knee. The patient reports pain and swelling in his right knee since the injury. He has been able to ambulate although he notes difficulty due to swelling and pain. The patient has been taking Advil as well as icing and applying heat to his knee intermittently. He denies any previous knee injuries.

The patient also reports right shoulder pain and bruising. He states he landed on his right shoulder when he fell. He reports tenderness with raising his arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling. Right shoulder pain and bruising.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 110/74 mmHg.
Heart Rate: 64 beats per minute.
Respiratory Rate: 16 breaths per minute.
Oxygen Saturation: 98%
Body Temperature: 97.9 degrees F.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Mild edema
MSK:
Examination of the right knee: Edema and ecchymosis surrounding the knee. Positive pain to palpation. Pain with flexion and extension. Full ROM.
Examination of the right shoulder: Mild bruising is present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and are reviewed today. No fracture is appreciated. No bony abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right knee contusion.
2. Right shoulder pain.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have advised him to rest his right knee and apply ice 2 to 3 times per day for 20 minutes at a time. He can take non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. If his pain does not improve with the medication, he will return to the office and we will consider formal physical therapy.

With regards to his right shoulder, I have recommended that we obtain x-rays of the right shoulder as well.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me on an as-needed basis.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joe Doe is a 59-year-old male who has a CC ice corn on my right knee that I bumped it. He denies falling or injuring any other body part. It's been causing him pain for the last 5 months. He has been experiencing difficulty with walking and has pain especially going up and down staircases. He has been taking OTC medications like Tylenol and bracing it.

The pain began after he hit his knee on the ice. He has been seen by chiropractor for this condition. The knee brace was tried to help relief, but with no improvements. She has also tried Tylenol which has not been very effective.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

CONSTITUTIONAL: Denies Fever.
MUSCULOSKELETAL: Reports pain in the right knee. Denies any other pain.

VITALS

Temperature 98.7 °F, pulse rate 76 bpm, respiratory rate 14 , O2 sat 95%, blood pressure 142/86 mmHg.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Examination of the right knee:
- Observation: Normal alignment.
- Palpation: Pain at the right knee joint line and along the patellar tendon insertion.
- ROM: Last term at 0° extension, limited flexion at 130°.
-Muscle strength: Full strength to L5 myotome.
-Neurologic: Light touch and proprioception intact in the right LE.
- X-Ray: knee: Osteoarthritis in right knee. Small osteophyte formation along the femoral condyles and tibial plateau. Slight varus deformity in the knee.

X- ray right shoulder: Unremarkable.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee arthritis.
- Medical Reasoning: Joe Doe is a 59-year-old male who presents with principal complaints of right knee pain. The knee has been causing him pain for the last 5 months which started after a fall on the ice. X-rays of the right knee revealed osteoarthritis in the knee.

2. Contusion of right shoulder.
- Medical Reasoning: Initial x-rays obtained in the office were unremarkable. I will recommend that the patient follow up to discuss continued symptoms.

Treatment options were discussed at length today. I recommended OT and PT 2-3x week for 6 weeks with a reevaluation to follow. Pain management with biofreeze qid was also recommended. Bracing could also be considered.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient was advised to follow up in six weeks to discuss improvement.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up of stage III non-small cell lung cancer.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent diagnosis of stage III non-small cell lung cancer.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports she was previously active taking mile long walks with her doberman. She states her husband is her support system and has been helpful with this new diagnosis. Her daughter has also been helpful.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports receiving chemotherapy consisting of Cisplatin and etoposide. She is also taking Zofran.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue. Denies fever.
HENT: Reports odynophagia.
Respiratory: Reports dyspnea and dry cough.
Gastrointestinal: Reports nausea.

VITALS

Vitals are normal including pulse oximetry.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: Neck is supple without cervical lymphadenopathy, or subclavicular adenopathy.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Rales in the lungs bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: No edema.

Integumentary
- Examination: Some erythema on the left anterior aspect of the chest.

Hematology/Lymphatic/Immunology
- Palpation: No enlarged lymph nodes.

RESULTS

Pathology report is reviewed and shows evidence of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule.

Chest x-ray is reviewed and shows evidence of mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Stage III non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: This is a new diagnosis for this patient. Recent pathology report showed evidence of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed that once her treatment regimen is complete we will proceed with further testing and hopefully tumor resection.
- Medical Treatment: Patient will continue on current regimen consisting of Cisplatin and etoposide. Her radiation will remain at 45 Gy.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Recent chest x-ray showed evidence of mild radiation pneumonitis.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed she is experiencing inflammation of the lungs secondary to her radiation treatment. The risks and benefits of prednisone were also discussed.
- Medical treatment: A prescription for prednisone 40 mg 1 tablet a day for 5 days was provided.

3. Odynophagia.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports symptoms of painful swallowing.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I advised her that her radiation pneumonitis is also affecting her esophagus which is resulting in her painful swallowing. We discussed the importance of nutrition and hydration while undergoing chemotherapy.
- Medical treatment: Prescription for lidocaine viscous solution to be completed 4 times a day was provided.
Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Patient will return for follow-up in 2 weeks.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 56-year-old female who is an established patient of pulmonary. The patient presents for follow-up of stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.

The patient is currently taking neoadjuvant chemotherapy and has her last dose of ESL platinum and atopic side a few days ago. The patient notes a little bit of shortness of breath that she noticed over the weekend. She is normally pretty active and used to walk for about a mile, but now she can barely walk around the block without becoming short of breath. She also reports a dry cough with no phlegm, odynophagia, not high-fever, but is endorsing an intermittent sore throat. She was a little bit of nausea and fatigue, however, she did take the Zofran that was prescribed and was given adequate rest. She does endorse dysphagia. She has her on Ensure, but every time she swallows its painful. She also notes that she does end up completely dehydrated at times.
The patient is also receiving radiation treatment. She is receiving a total of 45 grays. She also recently had a chest x-ray with results today showing mild radiation pneumonitis. She is endorsing an erythema to the anterior aspect of the chest; this is possibly from radiation.

She her last PFT results from a few days ago showed a 4.4 cm nodule in the left upper lobe. This is down from the previous size, but was stated to be approximately 5 cm. She is not coughing up any blood. She also has a Doberman.

The patient confirms that she was recently an avid walker. She used to walk for about a mile a day, but couldn't because of the odynophagia and dyspnea over the weekend. Her husband took the dog for a walk instead.

She also states that she is mentally and emotionally strained. Her husband and daughter have been by her side to provide support and assistance.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, weight changes, and anxiety.
Eyes: Denies visual changes. Endorses eye pain.
Ears, Nose, Mouth, Throat: Denies sinus pain, congestion, voice change, anosmia, tinnitus, vertigo, sore throat, and dental problems. Endorses otalgia.
Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain. No orthopnea, palpitations, lower extremity edema, syncope, or claudication.
Respiratory: Endorses dyspnea on exertion. Denies orthopnea, wheezing, stridor, chest pain, hemoptysis, cough, sputum production.
Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, rectal bleeding, melena, hematochezia.
Integumentary: Endorses rash, inflammation, redness. Denies pruritus.
Neurologic: Endorses HA and stress. Denies dizziness, numbness, paresthesias, weakness.
Musculoskeletal: Denies joint swelling, stiffness, or pain. Endorses back pain and muscle weakness.
Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety and depression.

VITALS

All vitals within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

- Constitutional: Appears tired and distressed but in no acute distress.
- Skin Exam: Erythema to the anterior aspect of the chest on the left side. No lower extremity edema.
- Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray from a few days ago was reviewed today, it shows mild radiation pneumonitis - this is due to the radiation directed to the left upper lobe.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The 56-year-old female who is an established patient of pulmonary who presents today for follow-up regarding her non-small cell lung cancer.

1. Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has a 5 cm mass on her last PFTs whereas only a 4.4 cm mass was present today. No hemoptysis. Slight improvement now that chemotherapy started.
- Additional Testing: We will obtain additional imaging studies after the chemotherapy regimen is complete. We will also do a postoperative assessment after completing radiation.
- Medical Treatment: The patient underwent neoadjuvant chemotherapy with ESL platinum and atopic side . She has completed 45 gray of radiation. She is not able to take hydro drink water, ice cream because of painful throat, However, she is able to tolerate 1 mile of walking.
- Medical Compliance: The patient is compliant with treatment.
- Patient Education and Counseling:Continue recommended dietary changes for shortness of breath. Continue to maintain adequate nutrition. Try to adjust activity level to continue walking at least 1 mile per day. Educated on current dietary restrictions to maintain optimal nutrition.
- Medical Followup: Return to clinic in 2 weeks or sooner if she has any concerns.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: The chest x-ray showed signs of mild radiation pneumonitis. She has reduced lung capacity.
- Additional Testing: Continue follow-up as needed.
- Medical Treatment: She is currently being treated with dexamethasone. For odynophagia, she is prescribed lidocaine viscous to help with the pain. Continue current regimen of chemotherapy with neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Educated on the use of dexamethasone and lidocaine.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the medical reasoning and proposed medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

- The patient will follow up in 2 weeks or sooner if she has any concerns.
- Patient will follow dietary changes to improve shortness of breath.
- The patient will begin a low-dose dexamethasone regimen.

The patient is a 56-year-old female who is an established patient of pulmonary.

Right flank pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joshua Reyes is a pleasant 18-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right flank pain.

For the last 2 weeks, the patient has been experiencing pain that starts in his right flank and radiates down into his groin. He also recalls one episode in which the pain radiated down into one of his testicles. Although his pain is intermittent depending on his fluid intake and activity level, he rates the pain as a 4/10 at its worst. Otherwise, the pain is a 1-2/10. He denies any pain with urination, hematuria, nausea, vomiting, or fevers, but recalls possibly having chills at one point. Over-the-counter ibuprofen provides partial relief of his pain. Of note, the patient has a personal history of kidney stones, some which were passed independently, usually within a week, while others required surgical intervention or lithotripsy. He also has several family members with a histories of kidney stones.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a personal history of kidney stones treated conservatively, surgically, and with lithotripsy.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient has a significant family history of kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports chills. Denies fever
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports right flank pain. Denies dysuria or hematuria.

VITALS

Blood pressure: Slightly elevated

PHYSICAL EXAM

GI/GU: No tenderness to palpation of the abdomen.
MSK: Examination of the right flank: CVA tenderness.

RESULTS

CT scan of the right flank was reviewed today, 05/06/2022. It revealed a kidney stone measuring 0.5 cm in size, located on the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Kidney stone, right side.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and CT scan findings today, we discussed the diagnosis and treatment plan. I recommend that we treat the patient conservatively at this point. I advised him to continue drinking plenty of fluids so he can hopefully pass the stone. He has been controlling his pain with over-the-counter ibuprofen and should continue to do so. I also prescribed tramadol 50 mg for any breakthrough pain. His primary care physician provided him with a strainer and I advised him to continue using this as well. I want to order a BMP, a urinalysis, and a urine culture to rule out any need for antibiotics. We will have him follow up in 2 weeks for re-evaluation. If he has not passed the kidney stone at that time, we can consider proceeding with lithotripsy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 2 weeks.

Kidney stone.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Joshua Robert Wainwright is a pleasant 28 year-old male who is an established patient of mine who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones.

The patient was seen in this office today. He reports that he has been experiencing pain in the right flank region that radiates to the groin for the past two weeks. The pain is intermittent ranging from 1/10 when the pain is mild and 4/10 at its worst. The only aggravating factors are increased activity, such as more exercise. The patient reports that the pain will subside within a week when he passes the kidney stone. The patient rates his pain as 7/10 after he performs alot of physical activity. The patient is taking ibuprofen when his pain becomes more severe and states that it helps. He also reports that he had one episode where the pain radiated to his testes. He denies any dysuria or hematuria. He also denies nausea, or vomiting. He does report chills. He reports a very strong family history of kidney stones. He also reports that he has passed stones on his own and had a couple of surgical removal of stones within the past. He also uses a strainer when he passes stones and has been actively straining his urine.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports chills.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea and vomiting.
Genitourinary: Denies hematuria.

VITALS REVIEWED the patient is hypertensive, and it is believed that his blood pressure is elevated due to pain at this time.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Unremarkable
Abdomen: Tenderness to palpation on the right side in the CVA.

RESULTS

CT.51 is unremarkable for any hydroureteronephrosis. There is a right proximal ureterolithiasis measuring 0.5 cm in size.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

At the time of the visit, we discussed the patient's CT scan results in today and gave him a print out for his records. We discussed his strong family history as well. We discussed how to continue the conservative management of his condition. I have recommended he continue to push fluids and advised him to continue with the ibuprofen. Since he is requesting for something stronger than ibuprofen, I am going to prescribe him 50 mg of tramadol to help with any breakthrough pain. He can take the over the counter medication ibuprofen for additional pain relief. Continue using the urine strainer. After today's appointment, I have ordered additional laboratory testing with a BMP, UA, and UC to be done at Outerloop Lab. It is believed that his blood pressure is elevated due to pain at this time.

INSTRUCTIONS

He will follow up with me in 2 weeks if he is still experiencing symptoms. At that visit, we will discuss further treatment options such as possible lithotripsy.

Regarding today's visit, the patient was very happy with the care provided today. All of his questions and concerns were addressed.

human_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of coronary disease, acute myocardial infarction in 2018, stage 3 chronic kidney disease, and knee pain. He denies a history of gout.

SURGICAL HISTORY

Patient reports placement of a coronary artery stent in the right coronary artery in 2018.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that he is a fan of basketball.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Lasix 40 mg once a day.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath.
Genitourinary: Denies changes in urination.
Musculoskeletal: Reports swelling in bilateral lower extremities and great toe pain.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 135/80 mmHg.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: Jugular venous distention up to approximately 9 cm. There are no carotid bruits.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi that clears when coughing.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the lower extremities: 1 to 2+ pitting edema bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute heart failure exacerbation.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient’s physical examination today suggests he is retaining fluid. His shortness of breath is also the result of an acute heart failure exacerbation. His recent dietary indiscretion may have contributed to this development.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained to the patient that he should increase his diuretic in the morning so that any increased urinary frequency will not interrupt his sleep at night. I encouraged the patient to limit his salt intake.
- Medical Treatment: The patient will increase his Lasix from 40 mg a day to 80 mg a day. We will see how he does with the increased dose in the morning before adding a second increased dose in the afternoon. Chest x-ray ordered to rule out any other etiologies.

2. Coronary artery disease.
- Medical Reasoning: He is doing well except for the heart failure exacerbation.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I advised the patient to limit his intake of salty foods.
- Medical Treatment: Repeat echocardiogram ordered for further evaluation of the heart murmur heard on his physical exam. I am going to call Dr. White and let them know that I want him to be seen by them.

3. Stage 3 chronic kidney disease.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to be stable.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I reminded the patient it is important to routinely follow up with his nephrologist. I advised him that he should limit intake of any potassium rich foods including bananas, oranges, and potatoes as they can affect his kidney function. I also recommended he avoid the use of any anti-inflammatories such as Motrin or Advil as they can contribute to worsening kidney function. If his pain does not resolve with Tylenol, I want him to call me, and we can discuss some alternative medications or therapies.
- Medical Treatment: The patient was provided with a referral to a dietician for assistance with his dietary needs. Tylenol can be taken for pain. Complete metabolic panel is ordered to ensure kidney function is stable.

4. Possible gout flare.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient’s recent great toe pain may have been a possible gout flare related to his chronic kidney disease.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained that there is an alternative medication he could take to protect his kidney function that would not result in a gout flare.
- Medical Treatment: Uric acid test ordered.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

I want him to call me in 2 days and let me know how his weight has been with increasing the diuretic. If he starts to have worsening shortness of breath in the next 2 days, I recommend he call me as we may have to admit him to the hospital for intravenous diuretics.
ai_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Frank Legends is a 64-year-old male who presents to the cardiology clinic today for a follow-up visit. He reports that he has been experiencing some shortness of breath for approximately 1 week. The patient notes that 6 months ago, he had similar symptoms and his Lasix dose was increased to 40 mg daily, which improved his symptoms at that time.

The patient has a history of coronary artery disease. The patient reports that he experienced a heart attack in 2018, at which time he underwent stent placement in his right coronary artery. He notes that the pumping function of his heart was decreased, with his last known ejection fraction being 35%. He has been watching his daily salt intake, although he indicates that his dietary habits have been poor for the last couple of weeks with holiday events. He reports swelling in his legs.

The patient has a history of stage 3 chronic kidney disease. He notes that he was seen by his nephrologist approximately 1 month ago. He is attempting to avoid the use of anti-inflammatory medications but had a recent episode of foot pain for which he took Motrin, although he stopped as soon as possible. He confirms that he takes Tylenol for pain and that it is effective. He has not altered his potassium intake as he reports that this information was not previously discussed with him.

The patient reports that he is watching the NBA playoffs and that he is a Celtics fan. He reports experiencing difficulty sleeping last night as the Celtics won their last game of the season.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Reports of swelling in his legs. Denies chest pain or syncope.
• Respiratory: Reports increased exertional dyspnea. Reports orthopnea but denies paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.
• Gastrointestinal: Reports changes in dietary habits.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he is currently watching the NBA playoffs.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Lasix 40 mg daily.

MEDICAL HISTORY

• Coronary artery disease status post stent placement
• End-stage renal disease

EXAM

RESPIRATORY
• Auscultation of Lungs: Bibasilar crackles with occasional rhonchi clearing with cough.

CARDIOVASCULAR
• Neck Vascular: Jugular venous distention up to 9 cm.
• Auscultation of the Heart: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard at the left base.

MUSCULOSKELETAL
• Examination of the Lower Extremities: 1 to 2+ pitting edema bilaterally.

IMPRESSION

1. Acute exacerbation of heart failure.
2. Coronary artery disease status post stent placement.
3. Stage 3 chronic kidney disease.

PLAN

I have spent a significant amount of time with the patient today discussing his current symptoms as well as the management of his chronic medical conditions.

For his acute exacerbation of heart failure, the patient will be instructed to increase his Lasix dosage from 40 mg to 80 mg daily. We are going to add a second dose, which he will begin in the morning with a potential second dose in the afternoon around 4 p.m. The patient will be instructed to avoid increasing his dietary salt. Medical clearance will be requested for consideration of a chest x-ray as well as a repeat echocardiogram.

For his coronary artery disease, a repeat echocardiogram has been ordered to evaluate the severity of the murmur.

For his stage 3 chronic kidney disease, we are going to order a complete metabolic panel. He will also be referred to a dietician for medical nutrition therapy.

*The patient will call with any concerns or worsening of health.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will call if he has any concerns or if he does not show improvement.
